content: any friends and fellow crafters today I'm going to show you how to quickly
make something that could take a century to grow an inch to a quarter of an inch
so let's go to the table and I'll show you how to make that in much less than a
century for this project I need some TP a spray
bottle with water in it and a a cheap cutting board I've got some white glue
also so what I'm going to do is I'm going to take some TP off couple sheets
and then spray it with the water it's easier than trying to dip it in the
water because it'll tend to disintegrate so this makes it easier to to handle and
now I'm going to kind of pinch that off what I'm trying to do is I'm trying to
get the shape of a stalagmite so I'm going to kind of pinch it roll it and
get a rough pointy shape there till I'm satisfied just squeeze it and roll it
till I'm satisfied there we go so I like it so now I'm going to put a little bit
of glue on that and that'll that'll harden that up so it won't fall apart
when we use it at the table and I have some laughs so now just do the same
thing just make more shapes will them up and I'll continue to do this until I
have what I want have as many as I need so there we go
got another one just keep going I'm trying to make different shapes and
sizes too all right so now I've got all mine finished and you can see well here
I've got one that's a double one I'll just cut that in half with the scissors
when I'm and it's all dried up but I'm going to put another application of glue
on here and this will harden these up quite nicely and there I've got them all
done so I think is here I've got a cutting board okay and I'm gluing some
of the slag mites to the board with the hot glue and this will help because I
get them in the in clusters that I want and you'll see in the next part why I
did this but yeah this is this is really nice too to get them into the groups
that you want okay so now I've got my TP and I want to join these groups I'm
using my water I want to join these groups together I've got some wisps
there and get those off and I'm going to use toilet paper to do that
so I'm going to kind of wrap it around the group spray it with water and then
squeeze it into shape and I can add a little more if I need to I feel I need
to fill it out a bit get the shape I want and then I'll put some white glue
on that alright and I'll just keep continuing around and doing the groups
this is a nice way to get those groups together right then make them like a
cohesive whole of one group and that's why I did the hot glue to the to the
board because then I can stick them up and then wrap the base around the
stalagmites like that okay see I'm just adding glue and this will harden up
nicely give them a nice solid base and I got one last one here so just finish
that up add some extra to get it how I want it and add some more glue and it's
good to go so we'll let those dry up if they look
like looking good all right so they've dried up and I want
to add some more glue just like I did with the slag mites this just really
helps solidify the bases and now they've all dried so I want to get them off this
cutting board I'm gonna use this scraper because I use the hot glue when I glue
to the to the board now I'm just gluing them to card stock bases cutting them
out I'm going to fill that edge in and that will blend it into the base very
nicely okay and also give a nice adhesion to the base so here I've got
one I've got glued to the base but what I want to do too is add a little bit of
texture with the glue gun so I'm going to pull it around the base and then up
and down these slag mites and those look given that kind of drip texture that's
really nice because they formed over you know such a long period of time it gives
them a nice nice texture to those pieces okay now I'm going to use quite a few
paints I'm using grey a burnt sienna a tan or coffee and then an ivory okay and
I'm using these lighter colors because these things are formed by minerals that
drip down wire the drips down over centuries from the cave ceiling okay so
now I'm painting on the gray very lightly or very wet actually some burnt
sienna painted some tan or coffee and then some I'm using ivory actually so
I'm using ivory on the tops and that's kind of simulating the the minerals that
are dripping down and forming these stalagmites
okay that's dry it up not want to use this pearlescent on it I'm going to dry
brush it on there that would give a nice effect of the minerals it'll really it
really look nice and give a little bit of a sheen so there we go
all set ready for your cave hey crafters I hope you found this video helpful and
informative if you have please give Scotty alack if you would
like to join with crafters who are like-minded like to make cheap stuff for
their table make sure you join my facebook group and my forum and last but
not least go forth and craft look at these pretty cave formations yes these
stalagmites and stalactites and take thousands of years to form with just
